question_details.query: What are the most effective ways to manage uncropped field margins on European farmland to support bumblebees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple replicated European trials, uncropped field margins sown with agricultural nectar- and pollen-rich mixes dominated by legumes supported significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins, though their value declined after a few years and required re-sowing [18]. Uncropped margins sown with native wildflower seed mixes (with mowing) increased bumblebee abundance—and in several trials species richness—over cropped, grassy, or naturally regenerated margins; inclusion of perennial leguminous herbs was an important forage resource, particularly for long‑tongued species, and some long‑tongued bumblebees preferred perennial wildflower mixes over annual forage mixes [19]. Leaving margins to naturally regenerate sometimes supported more bumblebees than cropped margins, but outcomes were inconsistent between years and often depended on thistles, which may require control; in some trials naturally regenerated margins did not exceed cropped margins for bumblebee abundance or diversity [20]. Sown grassy field margins showed mixed results, with some trials finding higher bumblebee abundance (and sometimes diversity) and others finding no improvement over cropped margins [14]. At a broader scale, farms implementing agri‑environment scheme options (including field margin measures) sometimes showed enhanced foraging wild bee abundance or diversity compared to conventional management, but other trials found no enhancement, and population‑level benefits for bumblebees were not consistently detected [24]. Evidence from wider wildlife studies also indicates that leaving cultivated, uncropped margins or plots can benefit bumblebees among other taxa [562].

question_details.query: How do different management approaches for uncropped arable field margins in Europe, such as sowing mixes versus natural regeneration, compare in their benefits for bumblebees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple replicated European/UK trials, sown margins generally supported more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated margins. Field margins sown with agricultural nectar/pollen mixes—especially with perennial leguminous flowering plants—attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins (four replicated trials), though value declined over time and margins required re-sowing every few years (three UK trials) [18]. Margins sown with native wild flower seed mixes and subsequently mown supported higher bumblebee abundance (and in three trials higher species richness) than cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins (five UK trials; naturally regenerated outperformed wildflower in none; one small trial found similar species richness between wildflower-sown and naturally regenerated strips) [19]. For agricultural forage mixes versus perennial wildflower mixes, mixes including legumes (all annuals in one trial) attracted greater bumblebee numbers at least in the first year, while one small replicated trial found common long‑tongued species preferred perennial wildflower plots over annual forage mixes [18, 19]. Naturally regenerated uncropped margins sometimes equaled wildflower-sown margins in bee species richness in a small unreplicated trial, but other replicated work found neither higher abundance nor diversity than cropped margins; their value often depended on thistles requiring control and varied between years [20].

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of planting phacelia (Phacelia tanacetifolia) as a floral resource for wild bees vary by location?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple European and North American farmland trials, patches sown with a high proportion of Phacelia tanacetifolia generally attracted substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, particularly bumblebees, with studies recording 8–35 foraging bee species [17]. However, one replicated trial in Greece found phacelia was not very attractive to wild bees [17]. In Germany, two trials reported no or relatively few species of solitary bee nesting on set‑aside fields sown with phacelia, indicating limited nesting response at those sites [17]. Broader evidence on flower strips that include phacelia shows mostly positive biodiversity effects across several European countries, with 19 studies reporting benefits but three replicated studies finding negative or no effects, indicating that outcomes can vary among locations [442].

What are the documented outcomes and challenges of rearing bumblebees in captivity for reintroduction?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Captive-rearing trials document mixed outcomes across species: some declining North American species (e.g., Bombus vagans, B. terricola, B. rufocinctus) were induced to rear adults in captivity, but other species (e.g., B. fervidus, B. affinis, B. pensylvanicus) laid eggs whose larvae died before adulthood; B. ruderatus and the Neotropical B. atratus have also been reared in laboratories [50]. In longer-term artificial rearing, B. terrestris queens decreased in weight over four years [50]. Husbandry factors influenced success: fresher, higher‑protein pollen improved reproductive output and queen quality; an 8L:16D light regime reduced time to first egg laying; hibernation at 4–5°C for ~45 days enhanced egg‑laying and colony formation but yielded smaller colonies than non‑hibernated queens; survival after hibernation was better for queens >0.6 g and with ≤4 months hibernation [50]. Field reintroductions of lab‑reared colonies showed variable queen production: some trials produced few or no new queens, while others produced good numbers [52]. Social parasitism by cuckoo bumblebees was sometimes high (25–66% and 79%), and was reduced when colonies were placed in intermediate‑resource landscapes and later in the season; other trials reported no parasitism [52]. Supplementary feeding in the field improved reproductive success in one trial but not productivity in another and did not reduce parasite load; released B. terrestris colonies foraged mostly >100 m from nests [52]. Overall, outcomes ranged from successful rearing and reproduction to larval mortality and reduced queen condition, with key challenges including diet quality, rearing regime, hibernation parameters, variable field productivity, and parasitism risk [50, 52].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different sown floral mixes on agricultural land for wild bees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across replicated trials, field margins sown with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes—especially perennial leguminous flowering plants—attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins (Europe; multiple replicated controlled trials) [18]. In the first year, agricultural forage mixes including legumes (annuals in one trial) attracted greater numbers of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix [18]. Three UK trials found that margins sown with agricultural legume plants declined in value to bumblebees over time and required re‑sowing every few years [18]. Fourteen trials in Europe and North America recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on sown perennial or annual flowering plants on farmland [17]. Ten trials (eight replicated) on farmland with high‑phacelia mixes found substantial numbers of wild (non‑Apis) bees—particularly bumblebees—with six trials recording 8–35 foraging bee species, although one replicated trial in Greece found phacelia was not very attractive to wild bees [17]. One replicated controlled UK trial found planted perennial leguminous herbs (including clovers) were more attractive to bumblebees in more arable landscapes [17]. Population‑level responses were mixed: planted bigleaf lupine patches in Nova Scotia apple orchards significantly enhanced Osmia lignaria reproductive success, but a Netherlands trial found no increase in bee numbers or richness 50–1,500 m from planted patches, and two German trials reported no or few solitary bee species nesting on set‑aside fields sown with phacelia or clover [17].

question_details.query: On UK farmland, how does sowing field margins with agricultural forage plants compare to native wildflower mixes for attracting bumblebees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three replicated trials found that field margins sown with an agricultural nectar and pollen mix of forage plants (including legumes; all annuals in one trial) attracted greater numbers of foraging bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix, at least in the first year (18). question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of increasing floral resources for bees at a landscape scale versus a local patch scale on farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Landscape scale: One large replicated controlled trial reported that average abundance of long‑tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of “pollen and nectar” agri‑environment agreements within a 10 km grid square (362; 21). However, two replicated trials in the UK found that, at a wider landscape scale, bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri‑environment schemes; one compared reproductive success of Bombus terrestris colonies and the other queen numbers in spring (24). Local patch scale: Across 14 trials in Europe and North America, substantial numbers of wild bees foraged on perennial or annual sown flowering plant patches on farmland; in 10 trials (eight replicated) phacelia‑rich patches generally attracted substantial numbers of wild bees (species richness 8–35 in six trials), though one replicated trial in Greece found phacelia was not very attractive (17). Four replicated trials measuring wider responses found: bigleaf lupine patches in Nova Scotia orchards significantly enhanced reproductive success of Osmia lignaria (one trial); bee numbers and species richness were not higher 50–1,500 m from planted patches in Dutch farmland (one trial); and two German trials found no or relatively few solitary bee species nesting on set‑aside fields sown with phacelia or clover (17). summary_details.relevant_summary: Across Europe, four replicated trials reported enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees on land under agri-environment schemes compared to conventionally managed fields or margins, including Switzerland’s Ecological Compensation Areas, Germany’s organic arable farming option, the Netherlands’ botanical and meadow bird agreements (with very low bee species numbers), and Scotland’s Rural Stewardship Scheme (including nest-searching queen bumblebees) [24]. What factors are known to influence the occupancy and productivity of artificial nest sites provided for solitary bees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across replicated trials, occupancy of artificial nest sites by solitary bees occurred in most studies, though one trial recorded no use; reported occupancy rates ranged from 1–26% of available cavities [47][80]. Placement relative to forage is important: nest sites should be within about 150–600 m of floral resources [47][80]. Nest design and materials influence productivity: reed stems and wooden grooved-board designs produced more bees per nest than several alternatives, whereas plastic-lined holes and plastic or paper tubes were less productive due to parasitism or mould; for Centris analis, cardboard straws in drilled wooden holes were more productive than grooved boards [47][80]. Repeated provision over multiple years increased use, with occupied nests approximately doubling over three years at given sites, and increases in foraging Osmia or local emergence where boxes were provided [47][80]. Parasites and predators reduce productivity, with measured brood losses from parasitism and other mortality in multiple studies; introduced earwigs and non-native bees sometimes occupied boxes [47]. Excluding ants from nest sites increased offspring production in a replicated controlled trial [46]. Under management, populations nesting in drilled blocks or stacked boards can increase markedly when conditions are good and plentiful floral resources are provided, indicating resource availability strongly affects productivity [54]. Species-specific suitability of designs matters: some species or designs (e.g., soil-filled boxes for a mining bee) were not occupied [47].

question_details.query: What evidence exists for the landscape-scale effects of bee conservation interventions, beyond the immediate site of action?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One large replicated controlled trial reported that the average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of ‘pollen and nectar’ agri-environment agreements within a 10 km grid square [21][362]. On a wider landscape scale, two replicated trials in the UK found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland under agri-environment schemes—one comparing reproductive success of Bombus terrestris colonies and another comparing spring queen numbers on farms with and without schemes [24]. Regarding planted floral resources, four replicated trials quantified wider responses: in the Netherlands, bee numbers and species richness were not higher 50–1,500 m away from planted flower patches, while in Nova Scotia orchards, patches of Lupinus polyphyllus significantly enhanced the reproductive success of Osmia lignaria [17]. A replicated controlled trial also found planted perennial leguminous herbs were more attractive to bumblebees in landscapes with a greater proportion of arable farming [17]. There is no evidence demonstrating effects of restoring natural or semi-natural habitat on bee diversity or abundance in neighbouring farms [6].
summary_statements: A large replicated controlled trial reported that the average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of ‘pollen and nectar’ agri-environment agreements within a 10 km grid square.
Two replicated trials in the UK found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland under agri-environment schemes.
One UK trial found that agri-environment schemes did not enhance the reproductive success of Bombus terrestris colonies.
Another UK trial comparing farms with and without agri-environment schemes found no enhancement in spring queen numbers.
In the Netherlands, bee numbers and species richness were not higher at distances of 50 to 1,500 meters away from planted flower patches.
In Nova Scotia orchards, patches of Lupinus polyphyllus significantly enhanced the reproductive success of Osmia lignaria.
A replicated controlled trial found that planted perennial leguminous herbs were more attractive to bumblebees in landscapes with a greater proportion of arable farming.
There is no evidence demonstrating that restoring natural or semi-natural habitat affects bee diversity or abundance in neighbouring farms.

question_details.query: What unintended negative consequences or limitations have been identified when providing artificial nest boxes for bees?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Bumblebee nest boxes often show very low uptake: multiple UK trials since 1989 reported 0–2.5% occupancy for several designs, and two replicated trials found 2% or less occupancy overall for bumblebee boxes (48; 80). Wooden surface/above-ground boxes are not the most effective design and have had low recent occupancy compared to underground or aerial designs (48). There is no evidence for effects of providing bumblebee nest boxes on bumblebee populations (48).
- Solitary bee nest boxes can experience high rates of parasitism and mortality: examples include 56% overall brood mortality for Xylocopa fenestrata in India (36% parasitism, 20% other mortality), 13% mortality (with 2% parasitized) in Germany, and 2% of bee brood cells attacked in shade coffee and cacao in Indonesia (47). Certain materials perform poorly: plastic-lined holes and plastic or paper tubes were less productive due to parasitism or mould (47).
- Non-target and introduced species, including European earwigs and introduced European leafcutter bees, frequently occupy solitary bee boxes; in one trial, introduced species used boxes more commonly than native bees (47). Earwig presence in boxes reduced use by native bees, necessitating exclusion measures (44).
- Some nest box deployments fail to attract target bees: one trial in temperate forest in Canada recorded no bees using solitary bee boxes, soil-filled boxes for Andrena flavipes were not occupied, and a trial with stingless bee boxes in Brazil found no uptake (47; 49). Reported solitary bee occupancy can also be low, with 1–26% of available cavities used in some studies (80).
- Placement and design constraints limit effectiveness: solitary bee boxes need to be within approximately 150–600 m of forage resources, and material choice (e.g., reed stems or certain wooden designs) affects productivity (80; 47).
- Introducing nest boxes stocked with solitary bees has no evidence of effects on farmland wildlife, representing an evidence gap (81).
summary_statements: Bumblebee nest boxes often show very low uptake.
Multiple UK trials since 1989 reported 0–2.5% occupancy for several designs of bumblebee nest boxes.

Wooden surface or above-ground boxes are not the most effective design for bumblebees.
Wooden surface or above-ground boxes have had low recent occupancy compared to underground or aerial designs.
There is no evidence for effects of providing bumblebee nest boxes on bumblebee populations.

One example of high mortality in solitary bee boxes showed 56% overall brood mortality for Xylocopa fenestrata in India, which was composed of 36% parasitism and 20% other mortality.
In Germany, solitary bee nest boxes experienced 13% mortality, with 2% being from parasites.
In Indonesia, 2% of bee brood cells were attacked in shade coffee and cacao environments.
Certain materials for solitary bee nest boxes, such as plastic-lined holes and plastic or paper tubes, perform poorly.
Plastic-lined holes and plastic or paper tubes were less productive due to parasitism or mould.
Non-target and introduced species frequently occupy solitary bee boxes.
Examples of non-target species that occupy solitary bee boxes include European earwigs and introduced European leafcutter bees.
In one trial, introduced species used solitary bee boxes more commonly than native bees.
The presence of earwigs in solitary bee boxes reduced the use of the boxes by native bees.
The presence of earwigs in solitary bee boxes necessitated exclusion measures.
Some nest box deployments fail to attract target bees.
One trial in a temperate forest in Canada recorded no bees using solitary bee boxes.

A trial with stingless bee boxes in Brazil found no uptake.

In some studies, only 1–26% of available cavities in solitary bee nest boxes were used.

question_details.query: What is the most effective design for an artificial nest box intended for bumblebees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Replicated trials report that the most effective design is a nest box entirely buried 5–10 cm underground with a 30–80 cm long entrance pipe; seven trials in the USA, Canada, or UK found 6–58% occupancy for underground boxes [48]. Wooden surface or above‑ground boxes commonly marketed for wildlife gardening are not the most effective; four trials that directly compared designs found underground, false‑underground, or aerial boxes were more readily occupied than wooden surface boxes [48]. Several types have been used successfully, including wooden or brick/tile boxes at the ground surface, underground tin/wood/terracotta boxes, and boxes attached to trees [48]. Three UK trials since 1989 of various non‑underground designs had very low uptake (0–2.5%) [48], and two additional replicated trials of bumblebee nest boxes reported very low uptake (≤2%) [80].
summary_statements: Replicated trials report that the most effective design for a bumblebee nest box is a nest box entirely buried 5–10 cm underground with a 30–80 cm long entrance pipe.

Three UK trials of various non-underground bumblebee nest box designs since 1989 had very low uptake of 0–2.5%.
Two additional replicated trials of bumblebee nest boxes reported very low uptake of 2% or less.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects on wild bees of introducing agri-environment schemes on European farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across Europe, replicated trials reported mixed effects of agri-environment schemes on wild bees: four trials documented enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees on scheme-managed land, including under Swiss Ecological Compensation Areas, a German organic arable option, Dutch botanical and meadow bird agreements (with very low bee species numbers), and the Scottish Rural Stewardship Scheme (including nest-searching queen bumblebees) [24]. Four other replicated trials found no enhancement of bee numbers or species under schemes, including Dutch meadow bird agreements in wet grassland, Spanish measures around a National Park and for steppe-living birds, and 6 m grass margin strips in England [24]. At wider landscape scales in the UK, two replicated trials found bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland with schemes—one comparing Bombus terrestris colony reproductive success and another comparing spring queen numbers on farms with and without schemes [24]. Syntheses of invertebrate responses under European schemes reported variable outcomes: studies showed schemes maintained or had little/no effect on some invertebrates including bee colony growth, while others found increases in invertebrate abundance or richness; one UK study recorded local but not landscape-scale increases in bee numbers under scheme prescriptions [700].
summary_statements: Replicated trials across Europe reported mixed effects of agri-environment schemes on wild bees.

question_details.query: How does sowing agricultural forage plants on field margins compare to sowing native wildflower mixes in terms of benefits for bumblebees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across replicated European trials, field margins sown with agricultural nectar/pollen mixes—often leguminous forage plants—attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins, and in three trials attracted greater numbers than perennial wildflower mixes at least in the first year; however, three UK trials found these agricultural legume margins declined in value for bumblebees and required re-sowing every few years (18). In replicated UK trials, margins sown with native wildflower mixes and subsequently mown supported higher bumblebee abundance—and in three trials higher species richness—than cropped, grassy, or naturally regenerated margins; inclusion of perennial leguminous herbs in wildflower mixes was identified as important forage, and one small replicated trial found common long‑tongued bumblebees preferred perennial wildflower plots over an annual forage-plant mix (19).
summary_statements: Across replicated European trials, field margins sown with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins.
Agricultural nectar and pollen mixes are often composed of leguminous forage plants.

In replicated UK trials, margins sown with native wildflower mixes and subsequently mown supported higher bumblebee abundance than cropped, grassy, or naturally regenerated margins.
In three UK trials, margins sown with native wildflower mixes supported higher bumblebee species richness than cropped, grassy, or naturally regenerated margins.
The inclusion of perennial leguminous herbs in wildflower mixes was identified as an important source of forage.

question_details.query: What factors, such as diet and social parasitism, have been shown to affect the success of captive-rearing and reintroducing bumblebee colonies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across replicated trials, success of captive-rearing and reintroduction was influenced by multiple factors: Social parasitism by cuckoo bees was sometimes high (25–66% in Canada; 79% in a UK trial), and was reduced when colonies were placed in landscapes with intermediate nectar/pollen availability and released later in the season [52]. Supplementary feeding had mixed effects: it improved reproductive success in one Canadian trial but did not reduce parasite load, and a USA trial found no increase in colony productivity with feeding [52]. Diet quality during captive rearing affected reproduction: freshly frozen pollen yielded larger, better-surviving queens and larger subsequent colonies than dried, frozen pollen, and higher-protein pollen increased worker offspring production [50]. Husbandry conditions also mattered: an 8h light/16h dark regime reduced time to egg-laying by B. terrestris queens compared to constant darkness [50]. Hibernation regimes affected outcomes: hibernating queens at 4–5°C for 45 days enhanced egg-laying and colony formation but produced smaller colonies than non-hibernated queens; queens >0.6 g and hibernated ≤4 months had higher survival [50]. Field outcomes of releases varied, with some trials producing few or no new queens and others producing good numbers [52].
